# Lake Superior Outflow through St. Marys River
# Data provided by Jacob Bruxer@ec.gc.ca, accessed Oct. 21, 2014
# Lake Superior data through 2013.xls!NBS
# LAKE SUPERIOR NBS CALCULATIONS USING ACTUAL MONTH & COORDINATED LAKE SURFACE AREA FOR CIS CONVERSION
# Apr-10
# (Residual?) NET BASIN SUPPLY VALUES - m^3/sec
#
# Meta data from cover email:
# Our office and Detroit USACE coordinate beginning-of-month water levels, change in storage, outflows, 
# diversions and residual NBS for Lake Superior, so I can provide that.  As for the other water budget 
# components, there are no coordinated runoff or evaporation datasets, you’d need to use something from
# Tim Hunter at GLERL and/or Vincent’s GEM data.  There is the coordinated precipitation dataset available, 
# but again you may prefer to use something different/better, such as CaPA from Vincent.  I was going 
# to mention during the hydrologic call the other day that I’m not aware of any records of consumptive 
# use/withdrawals from the Great Lakes, but that like groundwater flow, this is typically assumed to be 
# negligible (and on Lake Superior, it’s likely an especially suitable assumption).
#  
# I’ve attached a spreadsheet of what I’d call close to coordinated data from 1900 through 2013.  Note 
# that this data was last officially coordinated during the IUGLS for the period-of-record 1900-2008.  
# For Lake Superior, I believe the only major change then was the use of actual (rather than constant)
# month lengths, and this is reflected in the attached.  We haven’t officially coordinated any of this 
# data since, owing mainly to the fact we haven’t coordinated St. Clair and Detroit River outflows since 
# then and we typically coordinate all lakes at the same time.  But you picked a good lake, as the 
# Superior Board needs this data and coordinates it regularly, if only unofficially. 
#  
# So with the disclaimer that it’s not coordinated per so, I’ve added the years 2009 through 2013 myself 
# in the attached spreadsheet and also made a couple other modifications where I know there have been 
# updates since the IUGLS.  I’ve highlighted these changes in red.  I’m fairly confident these are the 
# best available datasets and are at least suitable to get you started (in the meantime, I’ve also CC’d 
# Keith so he or someone in his office can review what I’ve done). 
#
	JAN	FEB	MAR	APR	MAY	JUN	JUL	AUG	SEP	OCT	NOV	DEC
1900	-520	1160	-80	3340	3710	2210	5380	6420	7360	2050	-190	-1300
1901	-1130	-260	1340	3560	3380	5720	5200	2440	390	2900	-320	-720
1902	-890	60	1300	3630	4600	4800	3020	2120	2180	1790	1490	-500
1903	-340	-2000	2620	4290	8110	2500	4690	2580	3220	1370	370	-2220
1904	-110	950	1010	1980	6750	4220	2380	4280	3410	3470	-710	-1080
1905	-1470	990	2820	3050	5300	5490	4300	3690	4100	790	1540	-380
